Dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p:
On Monday, the 18th inst., the House of Representatives,
by unanimous consent, passed the Dalzell Bill granting an annuity
of $125. per month to yourself and Mrs. Carroll. This Bill is
now before the United States Senate for concurrent action.

The present situation is best summed up by the following
letter to us, received to-day from Hon. Charles Dick:

“Acknowledging receipt of your favor of the
11th instant, I am pleased to report that just this
afternoon the House of Representatives passed a bill
introduced in the House by Congressman Dalzell grant-
ing an annuity of $125. per month to Mrs. Carroll and
Mrs. Lazear. It may be you have kept daily track of
the Carroll-Lazear case, but if not I will say to you
that when Congressman Dalzell saw it would be impossi-
ble to get the Senate Pension bill through the House
he introduced a bill proposing that the two widows be
granted an annuity, had it promptly reported by the
Military Committee, and to-day by unanimous consent
it was taken up and passed. It now comes over to the
Senate and it is hardly necessary for me to tell you
that everything within my power will be done to get
it passed there before adjournment.”

We have urged both Senators Knox and Dick to do everything
possible to secure favorable action on the Dalzell Bill by the Senate
at this session. If the friends of this legislation will co-operate
at this time, as we have every reason to believe they will do, the
Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear,
- 2 -
present Congress will fittingly provide for the widows and children
of the members of the Yellow Fever Commission.

The introduction of the Dalzell Bill, granting an annuity,
was made necessary because Mr. Loudenslager, Chairman of the House of
Representatives Pension Committee, reported the Hinshaw Bill so amend-
ed as to provide a pension of $35. a month for Mrs. Carroll, instead
of the $25. Now enjoyed, without any provision for increased pension
for yourself. The House will, of course, take no action on that
measure, now that the Dalzell Bill, extending the $125. Annuity, has
been passed.

We assure you that Mr. Dalzell has done everything possible
to secure favorable action on this legislation in the House and Sen-
ators Knox and Dick will put forth their best efforts to secure its enact-
ment by the Senate.

We earnestly trust that our next advice to you may be to
the effect that the Dalzell Bill has passed the Senate, which will
mean that you and yours will enjoy an annuity of $125. per month,
for we feel confident that President Roosevelt will give the Bill
his signature.
